title: 115_hr1491
content: The Act is titled the "Santa Ynez Band of Chumash Indians Land Affirmation Act of 2017". It includes findings related to the Act. The Santa Ynez Band of Chumash Indians Land Affirmation Act of 2017 includes findings regarding the approval of a Memorandum of Agreement between the County of Santa Barbara and the Santa Ynez Band of Chumash Indians for the Camp 4 land. The Secretary of the Interior also approved the Memorandum of Agreement. The Santa Ynez Band of Chumash Indians Land Affirmation Act of 2017 ratifies the Secretary's actions to place land into trust for the tribe and assume jurisdiction over related appeals in Santa Barbara County, California. The Secretary's decision to dismiss appeals regarding the fee-to-trust acquisition of land in Santa Barbara County, California, on January 19, 2017, is ratified. The land placed into trust for the Santa Ynez Band of Chumash Indians on January 20, 2017, will be part of the Santa Ynez Indian Reservation and administered according to applicable laws and regulations. The government has ratified the decision to place land in Santa Barbara County into trust for the Santa Ynez Band of Chumash Indians, removing any restrictions on the property. The legal description of the transferred lands includes lots in the County of Santa Barbara, California. The legal description of the transferred lands includes lots in the County of Santa Barbara, California, as shown on the map of the subdivisions of the Canada de los Pinos or College Rancho. The legal description includes lots in Tract 16 and Tract 25 in Santa Barbara County, California, as shown on the map of the subdivisions of the Canada de los Pinos or College Rancho. Parcel 5 is a portion of Lots 3 and 6 of Tract 16 in Santa Barbara County, California, lying northeasterly of the land granted to the State of California. This legal description is pursuant to a certificate of compliance recorded on December 5, 2001. The legal document recorded on December 5, 2001, outlines rules and restrictions regarding land rights and gaming activities for the Tribe. It specifies that existing land and water rights of the Tribe are not affected by the Act, and restricts gaming activities on transferred lands. The legal document from December 5, 2001, outlines rules and restrictions for the Santa Ynez Band of Chumash Mission Indians regarding land rights and gaming activities. The document specifies that existing land and water rights are not affected and restricts gaming activities on transferred lands. The document also mentions that the Secretary of the Interior has authority over the Tribe under Federal law, including the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act.
